trial_identification.studytitle: Multidisciplinary Operating Room Simulations for Improved Teamwork and Information Sharing
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A simulation-based intervention for operating room teams to improve teamwork and information sharing and reduce patient harm

interventions.interventions: A one-day course involving a didactic lecture on teamwork and effective communication, three immersive scenarios of acute surgical cases and educational debriefs.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Harm, as defined by the American College of Surgeons' National Surgical Quality Improvement Program.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The year before and the year after the intervention, identified by chart review.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Behavioural Markers of Risk Index scores for information sharing in the operating theatre.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Up to 200 cases observed in the months before and after the intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Shared mental models as measured by a card sorting exercise, Situational Awareness Global Assessment Technique, and by counts of correctly identified information probes
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the scenarios in the intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Attitudes to teamwork and safety, as by the Safety Attitudes Questionnaire.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Before the course and approximately 6 months after the course.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Medical managment of the scenarios as measured by systematic subjective and objective ratings
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the scnearios in the intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Emotional intelligence as measured by the Trait Emotional Intelligence Questionnaire (Short Form) and The Cambridge BEhaviour Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the scenarios in the intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physiologic responses to stress as measured by heart rate, via a Zephyr monitor, and subjective timings of increased stress provided by participants via visual analogue scale.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the scenarios in the intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Communication patterns as coded from video recordings of the simulations. The codes will be time-stamped markers including who was speaking to whome and what type of utterance it was (question, statement, instruction etc).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During the scenarios in the intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Currently working in Auckland City Hospital on Level 8 or in Midlemore Hospital in general surgery operating rooms. Written, informed consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Anaesthetists not yet at ATY-1 training level Anaesthetic technicians who have not yet passed their final NZATS exam

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be asked to attend the intervention days by members of the project team and allocated a day according to their availability.
trial_design.sequence: Participants will not be formally randomised to a day. However, the order of scenarios will be randomised on a given day using the Microsoft Excel random number generator.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Observational research of operating theatre teams supports the proposition that failures in teamwork and communication are common and lead directly to compromised patient care and reduced productivity. High fidelity, immersive patient simulation is an exciting new technology that provides both a test laboratory for the study of medical error and health care teams, and a powerful medium for implementing change in the way health care teams function. This study is focused on measuring the impact of a simulation-based course on teamwork in the operating room.
